text:
I like it very much! Yes, this is a great lens on one of the big issues that’s causing a lot of complexity in our field.

Some random thoughts:

1. I’ve always wondered why the Unix command line and in particular its pipe feature is considered a good solution and what makes it so special. I don’t have a final conclusion, but I suspect the “fuzziness” of the not very clearly defined text stream interface has to do with it. Every other data format you list tries very hard to be precise in describing data structure and even types. The text stream a sort command operates on, just needs agreement on the used delimiter. When specifying function interfaces within a programming language we’re by default already in a much more precise type system (even in dynamically types languages), which prevent that level of ambiguity (and break-ability).
2. Human language also has this fuzziness: we can describe concepts without being sure that the person we talk to has the same definitions. Surprisingly, it works more often than it doesn’t, even though the receiver has a slightly different understanding than the sender. Programming languages break as soon as there is the slightest mismatch in syntax, grammar, or data types. We design data formats like programming languages. There’s is no room for ambiguity. By design. Maybe there should be.
3. The pipe-able Unix text stream “type” is a very loose specification of a type, and it’s kind of monoidal in nature — everything going through a filter command line program ends up as another text stream. The required structure to make piping work is minimal and doesn’t even touch on what the data in that text stream actually is. That makes it extremely generic and composable. The parameters and return values in function calls are very specific and usually mix strict expectations on both structure and data type/format. By that we’re creating countless different API calls that are all not easily composable.
4. #3 is also a not yet well expressed reason why functional/declarative is superior to imperative. Imperative code composes function calls over time (when to call what), and creates these huge, complex hierarchies and if you add concurrency to the mix it blows up even more. Other types of composition in imperative languages require additional structure in form of higher-level constructs like interfaces or design patterns. Pure functional composition and algebraic data structures allow a monoidal composition where you stay in the same category — you compose lots of things but yet they all stay the same type, just like piping on the Unix command line. There is some objective superiority in the functional or declarative approach (not sure yet which one exactly, although it could be both for different reasons) over imperative — by that I mean it can be objectively described and explained and it isn’t just a “depends on the context” issue. Unfortunately, I don’t know how to explain that yet. But the way composition works in these approaches is key. Imperative still has its value, but likely as an implementation detail between a functional/declarative high-level language and its low-level implementation on a machine. I know that’s controversial. Please @ me! :-)

I have lots more to say about this, but that’s already a lot to read so I leave it at that for now.

I’ve been thinking about this for a while, but more focused on data formats and structuring data and trying to stay away from the typical programming issues like interoperability for now. I came to believe that a lot of the issues we’re trying to solve are self-made and we need to break out of our own context to find better solutions.

Yes, YouTube will transcode the video. Alternatively, you can use `ffmpeg` in the terminal to compress and re-encode, or a GUI tool like Handbrake. Let me know if you'd like tips on this.

Quicktime is a good way to capture, but it's not perfect — IIRC, it captures at 30fps. I use OBS with a custom configuration to get an _almost_ flawless 60fps capture, though that might be overkill for demoing something that's not highly animated. (I'd love to find a way to get a _perfectly_ color-accurate 60fps video — if anyone reading this knows how, tell me!)

text:
"Is it really true that sort cannot be expressed in a pure form and decorated to fit into any context?"

If all of the contexts are only trivially different from one another, then this would be practical. However, "any context" covers a lot more ground than that. In the worst case, the decoration could grow to be as complex as the sort source code itself, and the decoration may also be tightly coupled to the details of the sort implementation. So you can have cases where it is simpler and cleaner to just reimplement sort from scratch for the specific context.

For example, if the context involves dependent types and program verification, then the sort algorithm needs a type which proves that the output is sorted, and that type will be tightly coupled to the implementation. If the context is Rust, then the sort algorithm is required to be memory safe, and must pass the borrow checker.

If the context is APL/J/K, then the sort operator needs to return a list of indices, not the sorted list itself.

What if the data to be sorted is distributed across multiple machines and is too large to fit into memory? What if the context is a pure functional language with persistent functional data structures? You need different sort algorithms for different contexts.

<@U5STGTB3J> - thanks for the detailed thoughts. Interesting stuff.
>  We design data formats like programming languages. There’s is no room for ambiguity. By design. Maybe there should be.
This is something that I agree with. We need less 'gear like fitting' and more biochemistry like flexibility. You still have the receptors and tags that bind to each other but in general there's more flexibility in how coupling happens - and if something doesn't fit it just kind of floats around (where it can be observed) rather than crashing and terminating. I think tuple spaces kind of explore some of this 'tagged items in a pool' model. However I think really tight fitting couplings with little tolerance become harder to scale up orders of magnitude. Notice how we tend to be much more flexible in service APIs (protocol buffers are designed to be backwards compatible) compared to function types.

>  I came to believe that a lot of the issues we’re trying to solve are self-made and we need to break out of our own context to find better solutions.
Couldn't agree more :smile:

text:
>  You need different sort algorithms for different contexts.
That's reasonable wrt the current composition models that exist. See my above comment about 'have to' vs 'want to'. The deeper question is what's possible 'in a completely new world'. As an example, if an operating system doesn't give you the freedom of free form binaries but just the ability to create pure functions and manages versioned state. Now even if you create languages with different source syntax they all compile to 'functions' and are then much more amenable to a different kind of composition. The point is that the OS substrate is providing the greater context within which Rust, APL and whatnot arise. In a completely different substrate, languages and these inner contexts would themselves look very different.

text: Perhaps a good example here are Lisp machines (e.g. Symbolics)? They 'material' manipulated by 'processes' in that OS are not byte arrays but structured data. So even if you have something non lispy that compiles into one of those lisp processes, it's external compositional properties are very different.

[December 21st, 2019 4:46 AM] stefanlesser: Over the last year I've spent a lot of time outside my area of expertise, mining some seemingly unrelated fields for inspiring ideas that can be combined with what we try to do here. One particularly deep rabbit hole I fell into was linguistics. As I'm slowly climbing my way back up into our world, I started trying to put some of the insights I bring with me from down there into a blog series.

My goal is to make some of the concepts I learned about more accessible to us designing and developing software. I think there is a lot that can be useful for dreaming up and building a more humane and democratized future of programming.

I start with very basic stuff, and go slowly, so there isn't much yet. I also try to keep the posts short (500-1000 words, ~3-6 minutes reading time). There are three of them right now, and you can start here: <https://stefan-lesser.com/2019/12/06/structure-and-behavior/>

Would love to hear what you think. Thank you!

text:
One of the big questions every next-gen language has to face sooner or later, is: Is it a suitable replacement for any of the top 3 languages in use which are JavaScript, Java, and Python?   Those languages have huge entrenched user bases; with tons of code, examples, and libraries. I don't think you can find a higher risk project than tackling any of those 3 languages head-on, but hey isn't that the job of the future of coding group, to spawn the replacement for these ancient yet powerful languages?  If we can't topple one or more of these giant towers of code, are we making any significant progress?

As as test case i took a very small Python program that draws a little tree, and recoded it in the Beads language, and did a comparison of the complexity of the API calls used to create the program. This is a subjective task of course, as assigning points to various API calls is debatable, but one has to at least make a stab at measurement, because without measurement there is no science; just fad and fashion. The two programs are really quite different, and I think just this tiny example shows the vast gulf between notations. The detailed comparison is at <https://github.com/magicmouse/beads-examples/blob/master/Example%20-%20Xmas%20Tree/docs/comparison_with_python.md>
